turn.text: Pardon, I didn't --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think it is not necessary to go so far as -- insofar as it (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: As far as vagueness is concerned but not in the terms of ultimate question of whether or not a woman is entitled to abortion at every point up to birth.

The text books on the subject as I understand once the embryo reaches a certain stage, they don't even call it an abortion, they call it induced labor, and becomes a somewhat different medical problem as I understand it.
But I would like to emphasize --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So somewhat of a different problems occurs so that fundamental right of the women not to bear a child?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Now that is a question I would not have an answer to in this particular case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is difficult?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To draw any distinction?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: It is and we are making the claim as spelled out at some length in our brief, that certainly up to the traditional lines of 20, 22, 24 weeks that is a right of a woman to have an abortion.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean a constitutional right?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That's correct sir.
I don't think it's necessary --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under which provisions of the constitution?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well I would rely on the liberty of the women in the Federal case of the Fifth Amendment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well the liberty of what, not to be deprived of life, of property, or liberty without due process of law?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's not unrestrained absolute liberty --

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's liberty that cannot be taken away without due process of law.

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That is correct and if our position more explicitly Mr. Justice Stewart, is that if there is -- if there were a compelling state interest, which the state could come forward with to justify a restriction on this fundamental right, you might have a different case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't understand what the right derived under the constitution?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, the right comes from the liberty of the individual or for example, cases like Skinner in Oklahoma, specifically talked about the right to bear a child, Meyer in Nebraska discusses that, then of course there are other privacy cases, the Griswold case which at great length in three opinions on prevailing side, discuss of the right of privacy.
The position in other words, is a position based upon both the right of privacy and liberty of the woman.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What this really have to do with the right of privacy?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well I would suggest that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There is any constitutional right to woman?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I would suggest that if a woman wishes to have to use of her body in a way which would mean disposing up the embryo that, that is a choice that she can make, and that the doctor in the exercise of his professional judgment can make upon her request without the intervention of the criminal law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's not then the right of mother, or to be a mother or not to be mother?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, it's certainly related to that, but if in the more narrow sense, it's the use of the woman's body, which she has the domain over and which this court should protect.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You give any status there or a posture to right of the father?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I've given a great deal of thought to that and I reluctantly come to the conclusion that it's the women’s right and not the father's right.
That it is her body, and that she should have the right to make the awesome decision whether or not to bear a child.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Either the way that you're also saying --

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that she can delegate that right to a doctor?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: A constitutional right that she can delegate?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I would myself not use the word delegate, she could consult the physician.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what we wouldn't do.
Would the constitution allow you to say that a doctor had a right make a woman have an abortion?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I would not permit the doctor to make that judgment against the woman’s will.
She is the one who makes the decision, just as a client.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: She can convey the right on him?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Constitutional right?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Dorsen, does your argument about her right to do with her body what you have suggested, have as it's ultimate conclusion, the right to commit suicide?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I'm not sure, I'm not sure.
I would be inclined to think it would, but I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So that the next step is a challenge to the statute which makes suicide --

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: There may well be such a statute.
I don't think that this case even presents the same type of problem.
We're not dealing here with the – a human being in the same sense as a suicide case suggests.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, it just seems to me your argument has this logical conclusion that if she can do this with the fetus, can she come in to the doctor and say saw off my right arm because I want it off and saw that off.
I really not – I am just asking.

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, I think if the doctor is exercising medical judgment, if there is a disease situation, if there is a situation where he would feel that he should do it, I then would say that she could do so in unrestrained way.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But previously you have suggested that there need be no diseased condition, no other factor except the direction of the woman to authorize the abortion?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, that is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then why should it be different on amputating the arm?
She just doesn't, she just --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Just doesn't want the arm.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: She just wants to mutilate herself and she wants to do it in a safe sort of way?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, I do have problems with that, I do have problems with that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why do you have problems with that Mr. Dorsen if you're not take the position?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Well, I take the position because the abortion is a well recognized medical operation and that the operation without any indication at all perhaps traces out the question.
I would --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then I am talking -- if you have the trouble with the arm, I think you would have trouble with the abortion, especially and a fortiori if you recall -- and you even thought that the unborn child had some rights?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: I don't think that this court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Certainly an arm doesn't?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That's right.

I might say in connection with the very point that's been raised here that Mr. Justice Clark, now retired, in article in the Loyola Law Review, 2 Loyola Bar Review, dealt with the some of the same problems that are before the Court now and he concluded after discussing the issue, saying, I submit that until the time that life is present, the state could not interfere with the interruption of pregnancy through abortion performed in a hospital or under appropriate clinical conditions.
And he discusses the argument that amicus curiae supporting the government's position here, take and concludes that their arguments are without foundation.
He discusses it at length and I won't repeat his argument except to say one more --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean that there isn't life?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: That's correct.
No, no.

What he says and I think I can quote the relevant passage very briefly Mr. Justice White, is that "to say that life is present at conception, is to give recognition to the potential rather than the actual.
The unfertilized egg has life and if fertilized it takes on human proportion, but the law deals in reality not obscurely, the known rather than the unknown."
In other words his position is not that there is no life, but that this is not the way in which the Court should approach the problem.
That we do not know that people have different philosophical and theological attitudes towards this subject, but they should not be determinative once a decision is made by a woman.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It shouldn't be determined on medical branch (ph)?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: It should be determined on the medical branch (ph).

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I see your brief relying on Griswold against Connecticut?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: Yes Mr. Justice, among other cases, it does.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I notice that it doesn't have any page; that says passage.
What is that page?

turn.speaker: norman_dorsen
turn.label: Mr. Norman Dorsen
turn.text: No I've been prepared, but -- I suppose it's because it's cited frequently in the brief almost every page, but I would like to go back in concluding.
I wouldn't want to suggest that by dealing with the question, we've been discussing from the past ten minutes or so, if I want to get away from the precise issue that judge Gesell dealt with below.
Our contention is that this language is unconstitutionally vague, that it cannot be cured and that this Court should therefore affirm the judgment of the court below.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you professor Dorsen.
Mr. Huntington.

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: At first I’d like to refer to the question of Mr. Justice Blackmun at the end of my argument that the question of rubella.
I think perhaps I was too hasty in my response to that question that that would not be grounds for an abortion.
I think that if there is a substantial chance that there maybe a defect in the fetus that it quite possibly be that psychiatric grounds would exist for justifying the abortion in that case.

Obviously, the prospect of the raising a deform trial would have a very definite traumatic effect on a woman and I think that would in the room of the psychiatrist to determine precisely what that effect would be.
Referring to the Professor Dorsen’s attacks on the vagueness issue and mainly that it’s interference with the exercise of professional judgment by doctors.
I would just like to emphasize the narrowness of our interpretation of the statute.
We don’t believe the doctor will be second guessed by a prosecutor or a jury.
We believe that if he in good faith determines that health grounds exist that that is the end of it.
I’d like to refer --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Isn't that necessary, under the (Inaudible) statutes, is that a necessary construction?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: I believe it is a possible construction and the logical construction which we are offering --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But is it necessary for health?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: Necessary for health.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And the juror is not capable of determining that from evidence?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: Well, we believe that a reasonable interpretation is that the word health is a medical test, in that if a doctor concludes in good faith that health grounds exist that that should be the end.
The sole question before the jury --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's rather an unusual criminal act to let the man charged with the crime to determine whether in good faith that crime ought to be performed?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: Well, we don’t believe it would be a crime, provided that he exercises the judgment.

I just like to point that this statute is not -- that the Government does not harass physicians with numerous indictments that this Court is going to be face with the flooded cases involving the physicians.
In the last ten years, I believe something like six or seven indictments have been -- six or seven physicians have been prosecuted in the memory of the chief of the US Attorney, criminal division.
In none of those cases that did a doctor raise the defense of good faith.
The position of the Government is to go after doctors to limit the enforcement of the law against doctors who do not make medical judgment to perform abortion on demand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And good faith?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: On demand without making a determination in each instance that health grounds exist.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On any chance that you have leave if he thought it was was in good faith, usually.

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: If he thinks that it’s in good faith, then he is protected.

If he believes that the health grounds, that there is some complication that would raise a medical problem in carrying the pregnancy to term, or if he’s psychiatrist, if the psychiatrist concludes that the pregnancy will have a harmful effect to her -- to the woman’s mental well being and they determine that in good faith --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who determine it?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: The psychiatrist or the doctor, those in medical tests and we believe that their judgment on that issue should be protected.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It seems to me that when you concede that I guess I -- you have always conceded as the too ambiguous to be administered.

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: No, we believe that it can be administered against those who do not -- for against people --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I can – how can they prove it, he said its in good faith and not judge to them out --

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: I think if a physician said it was in good faith and it was shown by the Government that at every single case where a woman requested an abortion, he performed it that that would place an issue his good faith in meeting the grounds of the statute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you don’t --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: For all you research have you found any instance where the doctor was acquitted?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: A doctor was acquitted?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: No, I’m afraid I’ve haven’t determined.
I haven’t read over the all cases to determine that Your Honor.
Well, that’s the case and if could well be.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you speak of good faith you link that up with medical judgment, do you not, a medical judgment made in good faith, not good faith in the abstract?

turn.speaker: samuel_huntington
turn.label: Mr. Samuel Huntington
turn.text: Yes, a medical judgment made in good faith.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Thank you, Mr. Huntington, Mr. Nellis, Mr. Dorsen.
The case is submitted.
